results_summary: Krill oil significantly improved knee pain during sleep and standing, as well as the range of motion in both knees, compared to placebo. It also increased plasma EPA levels and the EPA/AA ratio.
population_specificity: Adults aged 38-85 with mild knee pain attending the Fukushima Orthopedic Clinic in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an omega-3 rich phospholipid preparation from krill oil could improve cardiovascular disease risk factors, such as cholesterol levels, in dyslipidemic non-human primates.
results_summary: The study found that intermediate and high doses of the krill oil preparation reduced total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, and triglycerides while increasing HDL-cholesterol and apolipoprotein A1, with no effects on diabetes or inflammatory markers. No safety concerns were reported.
population_specificity: Dyslipidemic non-human primates with naturally occurring type-2 diabetes.
study_duration: 12 weeks (each dose level given for 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with krill oil (KOC) and/or buttermilk fat globule membranes (BMFC) could improve insulin signaling, mitochondrial activity, and synaptic signaling in aged rats, potentially delaying cognitive decline.
results_summary: The combination of KOC and BMFC improved peripheral insulin sensitivity and increased intracellular ATP levels in the hippocampus, along with elevated BDNF levels, suggesting benefits for neuronal health and synaptic plasticity. No significant effects were observed in the cerebral cortex.
population_specificity: Aged rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of increasing doses of omega-3 rich phospholipids from krill oil on erythrocyte fatty acid composition and plasma endocannabinoid levels in non-human primates.
results_summary: The study found that krill oil supplementation increased EPA and DHA levels in erythrocyte membranes while decreasing omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids, without altering saturated fatty acids. Plasma endocannabinoid changes mirrored these shifts, with reductions in arachidonic acid-derived mediators and increases in EPA-derived metabolites.
population_specificity: Diabetic, dyslipidemic non-human primates (6 subjects, 3 control, 3 treated).
effective_dosage: 50, 150, and 450 mg phospholipids/kg/day, each dose administered for four weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks of treatment plus 8 weeks post-treatment observation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of increasing Omega-3 Index (via EPA+DHA supplementation) on cognitive functioning, academic achievement, and mental well-being in typically developing adolescents.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the supplementation, only the study design and methodology.
population_specificity: Typically developing adolescents (age 13-15 years) with a low Omega-3 Index (<5%).
effective_dosage: 400 mg EPA+DHA (cohort I) and 800 mg EPA+DHA (cohort II) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether free fatty acid (FFA) extract of krill oil could inhibit proliferation and induce apoptosis in human colorectal cancer (CRC) cell lines, comparing its effects to fish oil and specific omega-3 fatty acids.
results_summary: Krill oil extract inhibited cell proliferation in all three CRC cell lines similarly to fish oil extract and induced significant apoptosis and increased mitochondrial membrane potential. EPA, a constituent of krill oil, also significantly reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis, while DHA and AA showed no significant effects.
population_specificity: Human colorectal cancer cell lines (HCT-15, SW-480, Caco-2).
study_duration: 48 hours for krill oil extract, up to 72 hours for EPA/DHA/AA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term triglyceride-lowering efficacy of krill oil versus purified omega 3 ethyl ester PUFAs in mildly overweight hypertriglyceridemic subjects.
results_summary: Krill oil improved high-density lipoprotein cholesterol and apolipoprotein AI levels more than esterified omega 3 PUFAs and reduced hs-CRP more effectively, though esterified omega 3 PUFAs were more efficacious in lowering triglycerides.
population_specificity: 25 moderately hypertriglyceridemic subjects (TG = 150-500 mg/dl), mildly overweight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if krill oil supplementation could favorably affect plasma lipid parameters and other markers involved in atherosclerosis initiation and progression.
results_summary: Krill oil reduced plasma triacylglycerol, large VLDL/chylomicron particles, and the TAG/HDL cholesterol ratio. It also improved fatty acid profiles, antioxidant capacity, and anti-inflammatory indices without adverse effects on TMAO or carnitine levels.
population_specificity: 17 healthy volunteers aged 18-36 (mean age 23 ± 4 years).
effective_dosage: 832.5 mg EPA and DHA per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of krill oil supplementation on cardiovascular disease risk factors and blood glucose control in participants with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Krill oil supplementation for 4 weeks improved endothelial function and reduced blood C peptide levels and HOMA scores compared to olive oil. After an additional 17 weeks, participants showed significant improvements in endothelial function and HDL levels.
population_specificity: Participants with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the oral bioavailability of EPA and DHA in krill oil versus fish oil (EE and TG forms) when administered at matched doses over four weeks.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in plasma or RBC levels of EPA + DHA between krill oil and fish oil formulations when doses were matched, indicating comparable bioavailability. Bioavailability differed by less than 24% across groups, with krill oil showing slightly higher (but not statistically significant) plasma levels.
population_specificity: 66 healthy adults (22 per treatment arm).
effective_dosage: 1.3 g/d EPA + DHA (816 mg/d EPA + 522 mg/d DHA), administered as 6 capsules/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of EPA and DHA from krill oil (KO) and fish oil (FO) and assess their potential health effects on lipids, inflammatory markers, and cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: The study found that KO may have higher bioavailability of EPA and DHA compared to FO, but effects on lipids and inflammatory markers were limited. KO also regulated more metabolic pathways than FO, suggesting different biological effects.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (specific populations not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified (same amounts of EPA and DHA from KO and FO were used in two human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of krill oil to inhibit osteosarcoma cell proliferation and compare its effects to fish oil, EPA, DHA, and doxorubicin.
results_summary: Krill oil significantly inhibited osteosarcoma cell proliferation by 23%, 50%, and 64% at 24, 48, and 72 hours, respectively, outperforming fish oil (which showed no significant effect) and contrasting with EPA and DHA, which promoted cell proliferation. The inhibitory effect of krill oil was comparable to low doses of doxorubicin.
population_specificity: Human osteosarcoma cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of krill oil (KO) and fish oil (FO) supplementation on glucose tolerance in obese New Zealand white rabbits.
results_summary: Krill oil supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood glucose and improved glucose tolerance, with effects comparable to fish oil. Gene expression changes in liver and skeletal muscle suggested improved insulin sensitivity and altered lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Obese New Zealand white rabbits (male, castrated and non-castrated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether krill oil, compared to pharmaceutical-grade fish oil (Lovaza), could extend lifespan and reduce mortality-related pathologies in long-lived male mice.
results_summary: Krill oil non-significantly shortened median lifespan by 4.7%, increased lung tumors (8.2-fold), and hemorrhagic diathesis (3.1-fold). It also modestly elevated bilirubin, triglycerides, and blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: Long-lived, male B6C3F1 mice starting at 12 months of age.
effective_dosage: 1.17 g krill oil/kg diet (3% of total oil in diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the available human clinical studies on krill oil to assess its safety, efficacy, and market status as an alternative to fish oil for delivering omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA.
results_summary: The review highlights krill oil's potential benefits in managing hyperlipidemia, inflammation, and arthritis, and positions it as a viable alternative to fish oil due to its similar omega-3 content. The study summarizes findings from 10 peer-reviewed human clinical studies but does not provide detailed efficacy or safety outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred from clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of n-3/n-6 PUFAs and astaxanthin, found in krill oil, as nutraceuticals for combating neurodegenerative diseases linked to oxidative stress in the CNS.
results_summary: The study highlights the neurological benefits of n-3/n-6 PUFAs and astaxanthin, including anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects that may prevent neurodegenerative processes and cognitive decline. Krill oil, containing these compounds, is presented as a promising natural combination for such applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of krill oil on cognitive function in elderly subjects using psychophysiological methods.
results_summary: Krill oil significantly improved cognitive function, as evidenced by increased oxyhemoglobin concentrations during memory and calculation tasks and reduced P300 latency during a working memory task, outperforming both placebo and sardine oil.
population_specificity: 45 healthy elderly males aged 61-72 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if daily krill oil supplementation reduces fasting serum triglyceride (TG) and lipoprotein particle levels in individuals with borderline high or high TG levels and low habitual fish intake.
results_summary: Krill oil supplementation resulted in a statistically significant 10.2% reduction in serum TG levels compared to placebo, without increasing LDL-C levels. The findings suggest krill oil may reduce cardiovascular risk, though individual TG variability indicates a need for further research with more measurements.
population_specificity: 300 male and female subjects with borderline high or high fasting TG levels (150-499 mg/dL) and low habitual fish intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of krill oil on cardiac remodeling after experimental myocardial infarction (MI) in rats.
results_summary: Pretreatment with krill oil significantly attenuated left ventricular (LV) dilatation, reduced heart and lung weight, and lowered mRNA markers of LV stress, matrix remodeling, and inflammation. Krill oil also increased the proportion of n-3 PUFA in LV tissue, though no difference was observed between pretreatment and post-MI treatment groups.
population_specificity: Rats with induced myocardial infarction.
study_duration: Pretreatment for 14 days before MI, followed by 7 weeks of post-MI treatment for one group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of krill oil versus fish oil or placebo on plasma and red blood cell fatty acid profiles in healthy volunteers, focusing on omega-3 index and cardiovascular disease risk markers.
results_summary: Krill oil significantly increased plasma and RBC n-3 PUFA concentrations, reduced n-6:n-3 PUFA ratios, and improved the omega-3 index more effectively than fish oil. However, both krill and fish oil increased total and LDL cholesterol levels compared to placebo, with no changes in triglycerides or HDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: 24 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 600 mg of n-3 PUFA per day (in capsule form)
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment phase, separated by 8-week washout periods

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of krill oil (KO) and fish oil (FO) on lipid homeostasis and inflammation in a mouse model of persistent low-grade exposure to hTNF-α, focusing on the structural forms of EPA and DHA (phospholipids vs. triacylglycerols).
results_summary: KO, containing n-3 PUFAs as phospholipids, effectively lowered plasma TAG and cholesterol, enhanced fatty acid β-oxidation, and improved carnitine turnover. FO improved cholesterol levels but was less effective than KO in reducing TAG. Inflammatory marker effects were minimal, with only slight changes in IL-17 (FO) and MCP-1 (KO).
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 hTNF-α transgenic mice fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: Similar doses of n-3 PUFAs (EPA: 5.23-5.39 wt%, DHA: 2.82-2.36 wt% of total fatty acids).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of krill oil compared to fish oil on clinical and histopathological signs of inflammatory arthritis in an animal model.
results_summary: Krill oil significantly reduced arthritis scores, hind paw swelling, inflammatory cell infiltration, and synovial layer hyperplasia compared to control. It outperformed fish oil in reducing late-phase arthritis scores but did not modulate serum cytokine levels.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis susceptible DBA/1 mice (14 per group).
effective_dosage: 0.44 g/100 g EPA + DHA in krill oil diet (ad libitum access).
study_duration: Throughout the study (duration not explicitly stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Krill Oil on serum lipid levels in hyperlipidemia rats and its impact on the growth of human colon cancer cells (SW480).
results_summary: Krill Oil significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC), LDL-cholesterol (LDL-C), and triglycerides (TG) in hyperlipidemia rats, while HDL-cholesterol (HDL-C) remained unchanged. It also inhibited the growth of colon cancer cells in a time-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Hyperlipidemia rats and human colon cancer cells (SW480).
effective_dosage: Different doses (low, mid, higher) were used, but exact amounts are not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Neptune Krill Oil (NKO) on reducing C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in patients with chronic inflammation and its effectiveness in alleviating arthritic symptoms.
results_summary: NKO significantly reduced CRP levels by 19.3% after 7 days and up to 30.9% after 30 days, outperforming the placebo group. It also significantly improved WOMAC scores for pain, stiffness, and functional impairment within 7 days.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease, rheumatoid arthritis, or osteoarthritis and elevated CRP levels (>1.0 mg/dl).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of Neptune Krill Oil (NKO) for managing premenstrual syndrome and dysmenorrhea and compare it with omega-3 fish oil.
results_summary: NKO significantly improved premenstrual syndrome and dysmenorrhea symptoms, reduced analgesic use, and was more effective than omega-3 fish oil.
population_specificity: 70 reproductive-age women diagnosed with premenstrual syndrome (DSM-III-R criteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioavailability of EPA/DHA from krill oil and other sources, comparing acute and chronic supplementation effects.
results_summary: The study found that phospholipid (PL) forms, such as those in krill oil, had higher bioavailability than some other forms (e.g., ethyl esters), but acute bioavailability differences did not always translate into long-term impacts. Methodological limitations and lack of standardized protocols were noted as barriers to reliable conclusions.
population_specificity: Human studies (acute and chronic supplementation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether krill oil supplementation (2 g/d) improved knee pain compared to placebo in individuals with knee osteoarthritis, significant knee pain, and effusion-synovitis.
results_summary: Krill oil did not improve knee pain compared to placebo, with no significant difference in pain reduction between groups. Adverse events were similar in both groups, with musculoskeletal and connective tissue disorders being the most common.
population_specificity: Individuals with clinical knee osteoarthritis, significant knee pain, and effusion-synovitis on MRI (mean age 61.6 years, 53% women).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether Krill Oil (FlexPro MD) is an effective alternative for managing joint pain and inflammation in osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Krill Oil's effects.
population_specificity: Osteoarthritis patients seeking alternatives to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines or commercial supplements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether krill oil supplementation (2.3 g of omega-3 daily) improved cognitive functioning, resilience, and mood in U.S. Army officers undergoing leadership training.
results_summary: The study did not find statistically significant associations between narcissism (measured by NPI) and success in the Army Ranger Course, but the abstract does not report specific outcomes related to krill oil's effects on cognitive functioning, resilience, or mood.
population_specificity: U.S. Army Infantry Basic Officer Leadership Course (IBOLC) officers intending to complete Ranger School (n=555).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Krill Oil, among other natural products, in repairing liver injury, improving fatty liver, and regulating liver immunity through gut microbiota modulation.
results_summary: The study suggests that Krill Oil, along with other natural products, can repair liver injury, improve fatty liver, and regulate liver immunity via multiple targets and pathways, with effects closely linked to gut microbiota modulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general liver disease context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on omega-3 phospholipids (primarily from krill oil) for obesity-related NAFLD and outline their potential in prevention/treatment.
results_summary: Preclinical studies indicate omega-3 phospholipids have strong antisteatotic effects in the liver, surpassing those of omega-3 triacylglycerols, with multiple mechanisms involving liver, adipose tissue, and gut. Clinical confirmation is needed.
population_specificity: Obesity-related NAFLD (preclinical focus, human clinical implications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 supplementation from krill oil could improve cognition and resilience among young military officers compared to a control.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant group-by-time interactions indicating treatment effect on cognitive functioning, resilience, or mood. Poor compliance, evidenced by lower-than-expected omega-3 elevations in the treatment group, may have contributed to the lack of detectable response.
population_specificity: Young military officers (mean age 23.4 ± 2.8, 98.6% male) entering the US Army Infantry Basic Officer Leaders Course (IBOLC).
effective_dosage: 2.3 g omega-3 daily (via eight dietary supplements of krill oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of bioactive fatty acids (including those in krill oil) on immune cells and inflammatory responses, as well as modern methods for their analysis.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) like EPA and DHA from krill oil modulate immune function and reduce systemic inflammation by influencing pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). However, specific clinical efficacy data for krill oil is not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of EPA and DHA from krill oil-derived OM3-PL/FFA versus FDA-approved OM3-EE in both fed and fasted states.
results_summary: OM3-PL/FFA showed significantly higher bioavailability of EPA and DHA in the fasted state compared to OM3-EE, and its absorption was less affected by food intake, suggesting a clinical advantage for patients on low-fat diets.
population_specificity: 56 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetic properties, dose proportionality, and safety of OM3-PL/FFA (a krill oil-derived formulation) in healthy subjects under different dietary conditions.
results_summary: The study found that OM3-PL/FFA reached steady state within 7-10 days, exhibited dose-proportional pharmacokinetics, and was well tolerated. Bioavailability was not significantly affected by meal fat content.
population_specificity: 42 healthy volunteers following a Therapeutic Lifestyle Change (TLC) diet.
effective_dosage: Single and multiple oral doses of 1, 2, and 4 g/d.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors, including krill oil versus fish oil, associated with n-3 LCPUFA levels in adults.
results_summary: The study found inconclusive evidence regarding krill oil's association with n-3 LCPUFA levels compared to fish oil. Higher ALA consumption increased EPA but not DHA levels.
population_specificity: Adult non-pregnant humans

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and tolerability of krill powder in humans and gather efficacy data on its impact on cardiovascular disease risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that krill powder was safe with no serious adverse events, though some mild gastrointestinal symptoms were reported. No significant changes were observed in blood pressure or lipid values.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects with mildly or moderately elevated blood pressure (n=35).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of ῳ-3 fatty acids (including krill oil) in reducing seizures, focusing on mechanisms, preclinical evidence, and clinical trial results.
results_summary: Preclinical studies support the role of ῳ-3 fatty acids in reducing seizures, but human clinical trials show limited evidence. Phase II RCTs suggest low to moderate doses may reduce seizures, but larger trials are needed for confirmation.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice, rats, dogs) and human participants in randomized controlled trials.
effective_dosage: Low to moderate dose (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore drug repositioning strategies, including "Big Data" analysis and crowd-sourcing, to identify potential new treatments for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
results_summary: The abstract discusses the need for new SLE treatments and proposes multi-pronged approaches like "Big Data" analysis and hypothesis-based drug repositioning, but does not mention Krill Oil or its effects.
population_specificity: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a nutraceutical containing Krill Oil, among other ingredients, could improve lipid profiles in psoriasis patients with metabolic syndrome when added to etanercept therapy.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in HDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the group receiving the nutraceutical compared to the etanercept-only group, suggesting a beneficial effect on lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Patients affected by both psoriasis and metabolic syndrome (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular and clinical evidence for the benefits of different omega-3 fatty acid preparations, including krill oil, in the context of NAFLD.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that omega-3 fatty acids, including those from krill oil, show potential health benefits for NAFLD, though specific results for krill oil are not detailed. The review discusses the broader evidence supporting omega-3 supplementation in NAFLD management.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) of varying severity, including steatosis, steatohepatitis, and fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of krill oil with other omega-3 supplements in increasing blood omega-3 levels and reducing cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: Krill oil (PL) showed the lowest increase in whole blood omega-3 levels among the tested supplements and was relatively unsuccessful in reducing cardiovascular disease risk compared to concentrated rTG fish oil.
population_specificity: Thirty-five healthy subjects.
effective_dosage: EPA of 150 mg, DHA of 90 mg daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with a blend of krill and salmon oil (rich in EPA and DHA) affects insulin sensitivity in overweight men.
results_summary: The study found that krill and salmon oil supplementation unexpectedly decreased insulin sensitivity by 14% compared to the control oil, with a more marked reduction (27%) after controlling for the omega-3 index. This suggests krill oil may exacerbate diabetes and cardiovascular disease risk in overweight adults.
population_specificity: Overweight but otherwise healthy men aged 46.5 ± 5.1 years with a BMI of 25-30 kg/m².
study_duration: 8 weeks per treatment phase, with an 8-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether krill oil supplementation improves knee pain, stiffness, physical function, and lipid profiles in patients with knee pain.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between krill oil and placebo for knee pain, stiffness, or lipid profiles, but a small improvement in knee physical function was observed.
population_specificity: Patients with knee pain (700 participants across five trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the therapeutic mechanism of Compound Ku-Shen Injection (CKI) in treating liver cancer and explore its traditional Chinese medicine compatibility principles.
results_summary: The study identified 16 active components in CKI and 193 potential targets for liver cancer treatment, with key proteins like EGFR and ESR1 implicated. In vitro experiments showed that oxymatrine and matrine inhibited HepG2 liver cancer cell proliferation, and oxymatrine suppressed EGFR expression.
population_specificity: Liver cancer (HepG2 cell line in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oxymatrine, a constituent of Ku shen, on cancer cells and its potential protective role against DMSO-induced toxicity.
results_summary: Ku shen demonstrated protective effects against DMSO-induced cell toxicity, and oxymatrine inhibited the G(2) and M phases of H4IIE cancer cells, suggesting anti-inflammatory and cytotoxic reduction properties.
population_specificity: H4IIE cancer cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nondestructive method for predicting gel strength and classifying ethanol treatment levels in kudzu starch gels using microstructural analysis and NIR spectroscopy.
results_summary: The study found that ethanol treatment densified the starch gel network, and NIR spectroscopy combined with advanced data analytics effectively predicted gel strength and classified treatment levels, with the UVE-SVM model performing exceptionally well.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on kudzu starch gels)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ultrasonic pretreatment could enhance the binding of puerarin to kudzu starch and improve its functional properties.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment increased puerarin binding to kudzu starch, altered starch structure, and improved gel viscosity and elasticity. Hydrogen bonding was identified as the primary interaction mechanism.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Kudzu celery decoction (KCD) on sepsis-induced myocardial injury (SIMI) in mice.
results_summary: KCD treatment improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial fibrosis, oxidative stress, and inflammation in CLP-injured mice, demonstrating significant protective effects against SIMI.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice subjected to cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) to model sepsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the functional properties of kudzu starch by applying six modification techniques to reduce its pasting temperature and increase solubility.
results_summary: Modified kudzu starches showed reduced crystallinity, lower pasting temperatures (except urea-alkaline treatment), and significantly higher cold-water solubility (>70% for extrusion-puffing methods vs. 0.11% for native starch). The apparent viscosity also decreased dramatically from 517.95 Pa·s to 0.47 Pa·s.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of action of Kudzu root in preventing and treating cerebral ischemia using network pharmacology and animal experiments.
results_summary: Kudzu root reduced neurological damage and cerebral infarction rates in rats with cerebral ischemia, primarily by mitigating excitatory amino acid toxicity and improving calcium overload. The study identified 84 active compounds and 34 protein targets linked to these effects.
population_specificity: Rats with middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Pueraria montana (Kudzu) could protect rats from kidney tumors induced by diethylnitrosamine (DEN) and ferric nitrite (Fe-NTA).
results_summary: Pueraria montana treatment suppressed renal tumors, reduced tumor markers, improved antioxidant and phase enzyme levels, and decreased inflammatory cytokines and mediators. It also enhanced body weight and reduced renal weight and food intake.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a kudzu leaf flavonoid (KLF) supplement on productive performance and egg quality in late-laying hens.
results_summary: KLF supplementation significantly reduced the deformity rate and increased eggshell strength, while also promoting beneficial gut microbiota (e.g., Bifidobacterium, Lactobacillus) and interacting with hypothalamus gene expression. The 0.6% KLF dosage showed the lowest deformed egg rate.
population_specificity: 500-day-old Hy-Line Brown layer hens (360 total, divided into groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Kudzu resistant starch on insulin resistance, gut barrier function, and gut microbiota in type 2 diabetic mice.
results_summary: Kudzu resistant starch significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, improved lipid profiles, enhanced insulin signaling sensitivity, and restored gut microbiota balance in T2DM mice.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if superheated steam (SST) could prevent agglomeration of kudzu starch during rapid pasting with hot water while preserving its microstructure and rheological properties.
results_summary: SST at 20% moisture content reduced agglomeration from 42.20% to 2.97% without damaging starch microstructure or paste rheology, primarily by decreasing swelling power and increasing pasting temperature. Slight structural disruptions facilitated faster water absorption but were not the main prevention mechanism.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on kudzu starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Kudzu root extract on bone and cartilage turnover, menopausal symptoms, and its safety across different dosing regimens in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Kudzu root extract significantly reduced biomarkers of bone resorption and cartilage degradation, particularly with three-times-daily dosing, and improved menopausal symptom scores. It was well tolerated with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Fifty postmenopausal women (mean age 54.2 years) with at least mild menopausal symptoms.
effective_dosage: Five dose regimens, including two capsules three times a day (specific dosage amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Kudzu-leaf flavonoids (KLF) could effectively replace antibiotics in improving growth performance, gut health, and bacterial diversity in Yellow-feathered broilers.
results_summary: KLF supplementation improved feed efficiency, enhanced antioxidant capacity, promoted gut epithelial development, and increased beneficial probiotic bacteria diversity compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 216 1-day-old male Yellow-feathered broilers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the thermal inactivation kinetics of kudzu polyphenol oxidase (PPO) in model and food systems to understand its thermostability.
results_summary: PPO in kudzu tissue showed higher thermostability than in crude extract or purified fractions. Food constituents like pectin increased PPO's thermostability, with pectin providing the strongest protective effect against thermal inactivation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enzymatic modification (α-amylase and transglucosidase) could improve the functional properties of kudzu starch for broader applications.
results_summary: The study found that enzymatic treatment reduced amylose content and molecular weight while increasing branching, solubility, and paste clarity, while decreasing viscosity and crystallinity. These changes enhanced the functional properties of kudzu starch, making it more suitable for large-scale use.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on kudzu starch)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of kudzu leaf meal (KLM) as a dietary supplement on broiler performance, carcass characteristics, and organ parameters compared to alfalfa meal and a control diet.
results_summary: Broilers fed KLM had lower body weight, reduced feed consumption, and poorer feed conversion than the control group, but KLM showed potential as a safe protein supplement in poultry production, particularly in regions with limited commercial protein feed availability.
population_specificity: Male broiler chickens
effective_dosage: 6% kudzu leaf meal added to the diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dry matter digestibility of corn stover and kudzu mixtures after solid-state fermentation with Pleurotus ostreatus for potential use in ruminant animal feed.
results_summary: The study found that mixtures of corn stover and kudzu, particularly the 25C:75K ratio, showed the highest in vitro dry matter digestibility after 77 days of fermentation, comparable to good-quality hay. Other mixtures also performed well, indicating potential for use in animal feed.
population_specificity: Ruminant animal feed (not human consumption).
effective_dosage: Varying ratios of corn stover and kudzu (100C:0K, 75C:25K, 50C:50K, 25C:75K, 0C:100K).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kudzu root extract inhibits HIV-1 entry into cells and its potential as a supplement to current antiretroviral therapy.
results_summary: Kudzu root extract significantly inhibited HIV-1 entry into various cell types without toxicity, blocked viruses resistant to Enfuvirtide, and showed synergistic or additive effects with existing antiretroviral cocktails. The mechanism involved inhibition of viral attachment to cell surfaces, independent of CD4 and co-receptors CXCR4/CCR5.
population_specificity: Cell lines, primary human CD4+ T lymphocytes, and macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adult kudzu bugs exhibit differential attraction to different soybean growth stages and whether this attraction is mediated by plant constitutive volatiles.
results_summary: The study found that significantly more adult kudzu bugs landed on soybean plants in the early reproductive stage (R1) compared to other stages, with females responding more strongly than males. The differential attraction was mediated by plant constitutive volatiles.
population_specificity: Adult kudzu bugs (Megacopta cribraria) and soybean plants (Glycine max).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of Pueraria flower isoflavones (PFI) by evaluating estrogenic effects and hepatic CYP activity, and to compare its efficacy with soy isoflavones (SI) in reducing visceral fat and preventing bone loss in ovariectomized mice.
results_summary: PFI showed no estrogenic properties or effects on liver CYP activity at human-recommended doses. PFI did not reduce visceral fat or prevent bone loss in ovariectomized mice, whereas high-dose soy isoflavones (SI20) showed some bone-protective effects.
population_specificity: Normal female mice (Experiment 1) and ovariectomized mice (Experiment 2).
effective_dosage: Human-recommended PFI dose and 20x that dose (PFI20); human-recommended SI dose and 20x that dose (SI20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate insulin secretion in response to a ketogenic meal in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study measured insulin secretion after a ketogenic meal in healthy individuals, but the abstract does not provide specific results on the effectiveness or outcomes of the diet.
population_specificity: 12 healthy subjects (50% females, age 19-31 years, BMI 19.7-24.7 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the function of the ketogenic diet (KD) in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and outline its potential mechanisms as a therapeutic strategy.
results_summary: The study found that KD may benefit AD by improving mitochondrial function, optimizing gut microbiota, and reducing neuroinflammation and oxidative stress. Preclinical and clinical evidence suggests KD provides an alternative energy source and addresses AD pathophysiology.
population_specificity: Individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the contribution of macronutrients and glycemic load to weight loss in a low-carbohydrate diet and examine the relationship between glycemic load and insulin secretion.
results_summary: The study found that carbohydrate-related measures (total amount, glycemic index, added sugar, and fiber) strongly associated with weight loss, while fat intake showed weak or no associations. Weight loss appeared driven by reduced glycemic load, particularly among those with high insulin secretion.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-50 with overweight or obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential health benefits of Christian Orthodox fasting, a dietary pattern low in refined carbohydrates and high in complex carbohydrates, on human health.
results_summary: Christian Orthodox fasting showed beneficial effects on glucose and lipid control, lower body mass, and caloric intake during fasting periods, but data on blood pressure were inconclusive. Dietary deficiencies were noted for calcium, vitamin B2, and vitamin D, but overall quality of life and mental health were good among fasters.
population_specificity: Monks and individuals practicing Christian Orthodox fasting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lifestyle interventions, including low-carbohydrate diets, on hepatic fat content and metabolism-related indicators in adults with metabolic associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that a low-carbohydrate diet significantly improved hepatic fat content (HFC), triglycerides (TG), HDL, HbA1c, and HOMA-IR levels. It was more effective in reducing HFC compared to a low-fat diet.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity and metabolic associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD), 8% of whom also had diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate short-term metabolic changes induced by the ketogenic diet (KD) in patients with drug-resistant epilepsy and identify potential metabolites or pathways for new therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The KD increased ketone bodies, fatty acids, lipids, and related metabolites, including catabolites of branched-chain amino acids and structural analogues of γ-aminobutyric acid and lactic acid, suggesting potential candidates for further anti-seizure medication development.
population_specificity: Patients with intractable epilepsy undergoing KD therapy (medium-chain triglyceride KD or modified Atkins diet using MCT oil).
